metadata.case_name: Appellants v. Harnam Singh and Gurmej Singh

facts.text: The two appellants are admittedly the first cousins of the respondent, Harnam Singh, and belong to village Gillanwali, Tahsil Batala, District Gurdaspur.
Gurmej Singh, respondent No. 2, is a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree.

The appellants sued for a declaration that the deed of adoption executed by Harnam Singh on July 30, 1940, adopting Gurmej Singh was invalid and could not affect the reversionary rights of the appellants after the death of Harnam Singh.

The appellants' case was that under the Customary Law of Gurdaspur District applicable to the Gill Jats of village Gillanwali, Harnam Singh could only adopt a near collateral and Gurmej Singh being a distant collateral his adoption was invalid.
The defence was a denial of the plaintiffs' claim.

Both the trial Judge (Senior Subordinate Judge, Gurdaspur, Judgment dated 31st July, 1941, Suit No. 80 of 1940) and the District Judge, Gurdaspur (Appeal No. 91 of 1941, Judgment dated 14th January, 1942) held that the factum and the validity of the adoption were fully established and dismissed the suit.
High Court of Lahore (Civil Regular Second Appeal No. 450 of 1942, Trevor Harries C.J. and Mahajan J., Judgment dated 12th July, 1944) confirmed the dismissal.
Appeal by Special Leave granted by His Majesty in Council, dated 30th October, 1945.

The deed of adoption, Exhibit D.1, recites that Harnam Singh had no male issue who could perform his kirya karam ceremony after his death, that Gurmej Singh had been brought up while he was an infant by his wife and that he had adopted him according to the prevailing custom. The recital continues that since the adoption he had been treating and calling Gurmej Singh as his adopted son. This fact was well-known in the village and the adoptee was enjoying all rights of a son. He had executed a formal document in his favour in order to put an end to any dispute which might be raised about his adoption. As adopted son he made him the owner of all of his property.

legal_issues.text: Whether the factum of adoption of Gurmej Singh by Harnam Singh was established.

Whether under the Customary Law of Gurdaspur District applicable to Gill Jats of village Gillanwali, as per Question 9 of the Riwaj-i-am of 1913, a collateral in the 8th degree (Gurmej Singh) could be validly adopted, or whether the adoption was restricted to near collaterals only in a mandatory sense.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under the Customary Law of Gurdaspur District applicable to the Gill Jats of village Gillanwali, Harnam Singh could only adopt a near collateral and Gurmej Singh being a distant collateral in the 8th degree his adoption was invalid. The expression 'near collaterals only' must be construed to mean a collateral up to the third degree and does not cover the case of a remote collateral in the 8th degree. The restriction as regards the degree of relationship of the adoptee is mandatory and cannot be ignored.

respondent_arguments.text: Denial of the plaintiffs' claim. The factum of adoption is established by the deed and subsequent conduct. The custom does not mandatorily restrict adoption to near collaterals.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Customary Law; Jowala v. Diwan Singh; Basant Singh v. Brij Raj Saran Singh

court_reasoning.text: The first question regarding the factum of adoption need not detain us long. The deed of adoption, Exhibit D.1, and subsequent conduct provide ample evidence to sustain the finding on the factum of adoption.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ample evidence sustains the factum of adoption.

court_reasoning.text: The main question is whether under the terms of the Riwaj-i-am applicable to the parties, Gurmej Singh being a collateral of Harnam Singh in the 8th degree could be validly adopted. The custom recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in derogation of the general custom and those who set up such a custom must prove it by clear and unequivocal language. The language 'near collaterals only' is ambiguous and not defined, provides no warrant for limiting to a certain degree, amounts to no more than an expression of a wish, and is not mandatory. The provision that the right of selection rests with the person adopting detracts from the mandatory nature.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The expression 'near collaterals only' is directory, not mandatory.

court_reasoning.text: The basic idea underlying a customary adoption prevalent in the Punjab is the appointment of an heir to the adopter with a view to associate him in his agricultural pursuits and family affairs, secular in character unlike Hindu Law. No emphasis is laid on ceremonies and great latitude is allowed in selection. Rules relating to preferences in selection are directory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Customary adoption in Punjab is secular; rules are directory.

court_reasoning.text: Cited cases show that even peremptory language in Riwaj-i-am is treated as directory: e.g., Jiwan Singh v. Pal Singh (adoption of 9th degree collateral valid); Sant Singh v. Mula (distant over nearer ok); Chanan Singh v. Buta Singh (formalites indicatory); Jowala v. Dewan Singh (4th degree ok); Basant Singh v. Brij Raj Saran Singh (different gotra ok). No case where declarations held mandatory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Precedents confirm directory nature of such rules.

holdings.text: The factum of adoption is established.
Under Punjab Customary Law, the restriction in Riwaj-i-am to 'near collaterals only' is directory, not mandatory; adopter has right of selection including distant collaterals like 8th degree.

precedents_cited.relevance: Adoption of 4th degree collateral valid among Jats though nearer alive; Riwaj-i-am entry merely indicatory.

precedents_cited.case_name: Basant Singh v. Brij Raj Saran Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Restriction in Riwaj-i-am to same gotra is recommendatory; different gotra may be adopted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jiwan Singh and Another v. Pal Singh and Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Among Randhawa Jats, adoption by deed of 9th degree collateral of 16 years valid despite nearer collaterals and age requirement; provision recommendatory.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sant Singh v. Mula and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Among Jats, may appoint heir from descendants of ancestor, not necessarily nearest; clause advisory.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chanan Singh v. Buta Singh and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Details in Riwaj-i-am indicatory, not mandatory; no gathering of brotherhood immaterial if conduct shows adoption.

statutes_cited.name: Riwaj-i-am of Gurdaspur District, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Recorded custom on adoption requiring near collaterals only held directory, not mandatory.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the High Court, District Judge, and trial court's findings that the factum and validity of the adoption of Gurmej Singh by Harnam Singh are established under Punjab Customary Law, as the restriction to near collaterals is directory.

key_quotes.text: "The custom recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in derogation of the general custom and those who set up such a custom must prove it by clear and unequivocal language."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains burden and why custom not proved as mandatory.

key_quotes.text: "The basic idea underlying a customary adoption prevalent in the Punjab is the appointment of an heir to the adopter... secular in character unlike Hindu Law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes Punjab custom from Hindu Law, justifying directory rules.

key_quotes.text: "Whether a particular rule recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is mandatory or directory must depend on what is the essential characteristic of the custom."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key test applied to hold rules directory.
